comment._content: What a wonderful shot...look at the joy in those faces!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/starycat] I know! It's as if all their Christmases have come at once...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: This is brilliant, the excitement and sense of expectation, the clothes - macs, oilskins, caps, skullcaps, ties, sellophane collars, school ties, one man with a pipe, brilliant!

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Would love to know what time of day the ferry got in, and whether some of these boys were captured mitching by a photographer from a national newspaper...
(For non-Irish people, and maybe even those outside Dublin(?), mitching was truanting.)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 59890603@N07
comment._content:
When kids still looked nice, such a long time ago...
Now they run around with ipods, trousers hanging too low, hair standing up in spikes... shudder

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/1920sberlin] But does every generation (since time immemorial) not shudder at the goings-on of the current crop of youth?  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 59890603@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] No! It is of course not uncommon and it does happen a lot, but not every young generation feels the need or has the opportunities to rebel, be wild, do their own thing.
I bet none of these boys had much of a say in the clothes they wore, or their hairstyle, most of them wouldn't have dared to 'demand' the latest gadget or toy, most were given socks and sweaters for holidays and wouldn't complain.
In the 1920s we had the teenagers with some money in their pocket who went wild, people shook their heads at those youngsters, but most other youngsters didn't have the time or money to be wild flappers.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: If you look at this photograph with an unjaundiced eye you will see that there is a terrific mix of privilege and underprivilege, well off and positively disadvantaged.  The one common denominator was that they were (for the most part) boys together waiting to see their hero come ashore without any awareness of class or creed, status or poverty.  That's what makes this so very very good!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I know! Have to say I've a big grá for this one - sheer unadulterated excitement at an event that wouldn't have been quickly forgotten...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

This was taken in August when the boys were on school holidays.
